ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: ImageCLEF annotation with explicit context-aware kernel maps

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The general recipe of kernel methods, such as support vector machines (SVMs), includes a preliminary step of hand-crafting or designing similarity kernels. This process, which has been extensively studied during the last decade, has proven to be relatively successful in solving many pattern recognition problems including image annotation. However, many proposed solutions for kernel design, consider similarity between data by taking into account only their content and without context. In this paper, we propose an alternative that upgrades and further enhances usual kernels by making them context-aware. The method is based on the optimization of an objective function mixing content, regularization and also context. We will show that the underlying kernel solution converges to a positive semi-definite fixed-point, which can also be expressed as a dot product involving “explicit” kernel maps. When plugging these explicit context-aware kernel maps into support vector machines, performances substantially improve and outperform competitors for the hard task of image annotation using a recent ImageCLEF annotation benchmark.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: With the new era of social medias, there is an exponential growth of raw image collections in the Web and this makes their manual annotation and search completely out of reach. With this growth rate, there is an urgent need to deploy reliable automatic solutions able to efficiently and effectively annotate very large image collections in order to handle numerous application domains, ranging from multimedia, to surveillance, through medical and remote sensing applications.

Automatic image annotation is one of the major challenges in computer vision and machine learning. It consists in learning intricate relationships between keywords (a.k.a concepts/labels) and training images, in order to assign list of keywords to newly observed visual contents (see for instance [20, 34, 38, 41, 43, 55, 57, 61, 64, 77]). These concepts may either correspond to well defined physical entities (pedestrians, cars, etc.) or to high level, fine-grained notions resulting from the interaction of many entities into scenes (parties, fights, etc.) [15, 19]. In both cases, image annotation is challenging due to the perplexity when assigning concepts to scenes especially when the number of possible concepts is taken from a large vocabulary and when analyzing highly semantic and variable content.

Section2.Heading: Related work
Section2.Para: Early image annotation techniques are content-based (e.g. [14, 15, 21, 34, 35, 92]). These methods model straightforward “concept–image” relationships and learn how to assign concepts to new images; they first describe image observations using low level visual features (color, texture, shape, etc.), treat each concept as an independent class, and then train the corresponding concept-specific classifier to identify (separately) images belonging to that concept using a variety of machine learning and inference techniques, either generative or discriminative, such as latent Dirichlet allocation [2, 8, 89], hidden Markov models [42], conditional random fields [32], density estimation [14], probabilistic latent semantic analysis [54, 86], Bayes point machines [16], nearest neighbors, ranking and distance learning [29, 52, 53, 91], neural and support vector networks [17, 23, 27, 40], etc. Extensions of these methods achieve structured output predictions [75, 78] by modeling not only “concept–image” relationships, but also “concept–concept” dependencies [7, 60].

A second family of annotation methods extends the previous work by modeling “image–image” relationships during label inference [12, 25, 66, 76, 83]; among these techniques graph-based methods (including graph Laplacian [4, 5]) are particularly popular. In these methods, training (labeled) and test (unlabeled) images are modeled with graphs, where nodes correspond to images and edges capture “image–image” relationships; precisely visual similarity. Then, label inference is achieved by diffusing annotations from labeled to unlabeled data in a transductive setting [3], through the manifold enclosing both training and test data. In practice, smoothness and cluster assumptions [58] are considered to design accurate decision functions for label inference. Note that the success of these methods is highly dependent on whether images satisfy the manifold assumption (i.e., data lie on a manifold). Nevertheless, and excepting few works (see for instance [48, 49]), many of these techniques may fail when the manifold assumption does not hold, or when data are heterogeneous leading to highly spread and hard to model distributions as in social networks.
This also happens in the ImageCLEF database, used in our experiments, where “image–image” links correspond to other kinds of relationships rather than visual continuity.

Besides the limitation discussed above, the two aforementioned families of annotation methods heavily rely on their visual content for image annotation. Due to the semantic gap, they are unable to fully explore the semantic information inside images; this comes from the statistical inconsistency of low level features with respect to the learned concepts and also complexity of scenes. Hence, a third family of annotation methods, referred to as context-based (e.g., [18, 36, 37, 46, 47, 72, 85]), has emerged that takes advantage of extra information, such as contextual cues which could be relatively abundant (as in social medias [30, 31]), in order to better capture the correlations between images and their semantic concepts. Early methods emerged for text documents in social networks [93] and now recent work is handling visual content annotation, in different contexts; such as [45] that uses links as context in social networks to propagate image tags and the method of [74] that uses friendship connections and conditional random fields in order to improve the performance of photo annotation. To improve annotations, other works consider distances between tags using Flickr [87, 88], context information taken from personal calendars [22], language models and Web data [36, 46, 47], Ontologies, Wikipedia and WordNet [6, 9, 26, 33, 44, 63, 69, 73, 79], GPS locations, visual appearance and multiple cues [13, 29, 90].

Section2.Heading: Motivation and contribution
Section2.Para:
Among image annotation methods cited earlier, those based on machine learning and particularly kernel methods (such as SVMs) are particularly successful
See for instance the periodic and the challenging ImageCLEF benchmark [59, 82]. but their success remains highly dependent on the choice of kernels. The latter, defined as symmetric and positive semi-definite functions [71], should reserve large values to very similar content and vice-versa. Usual kernels consider similarities as decreasing functions of distances between images (e.g., [39, 56]) or proportional to the quality of aligning primitives inside images (e.g., [1, 11, 24, 28, 50, 70, 84]). In both cases, kernels rely only on the intrinsic visual properties of images without taking into account their contextual cues.

We are interested, in this work, in the integration of context in kernels in order to further enhance their discrimination power, when addressing image annotation, while ensuring their positive definiteness and also their efficiency during training and testing. The guiding principle of our method relies on a basic assertion: kernels should not depend only on the intrinsic appearance of images (as images with the same semantic may have different appearances and vice-versa), but also on extrinsic information taken from different sources of knowledge including context. The designed family of kernels, takes high values not only when images share the same content but also the same context. The context of an image is defined as the set of images sharing links (e.g., tags in social networks) and exhibiting better semantic descriptions, compared to both pure visual and tag based descriptions. The issue of combining context and visual content for image annotation and search is not novel (see for instance [13, 22, 90] and related work discussed earlier in Sect. 1.1), but the novel part of this work aims to integrate semantic context (taken from interconnected data) in kernel design to enhance classification and annotation, guarantee its efficiency, and plug these kernels in support vector machines to take benefit from their well established generalization power [80].

A closely related machine learning solution, that integrates different sources of features (including contextual cues), is based on multiple kernel learning (MKL) [62]. The latter aims to build kernels as (convex or sparse) linear combinations of usual kernels and the underlying features that could be taken from different contextual cues. Our proposed solution is different from MKL. Indeed, combining multiple contextual cues, via MKL, is different from the integration of context in kernels; the former seeks to learn and select better combination/fusion of features and kernels, while the latter cares about designing kernels which take high values not only when images share the same visual content but also the same context, thereby restoring similarity between these images. Furthermore, and in contrast to our method, MKL can be applied only when all the sources of features are available which is not always the case in practice.

In this paper, we introduce a novel kernel learning method for image annotation which takes into account the context. Through this work, an image database is modeled as a graph where nodes are pictures and edges are weighted proportionally to the number of shared tags between pictures. The proposed kernel design method is based on the optimization of an objective function mixing a visual fidelity term, a context criterion and a regularization term. The visual fidelity term encourages high kernel values between images sharing similar intrinsic visual contents. The context criterion, considers the local graph structure and allows us to further enhance the relevance of our designed kernel, by diffusing and restoring the similarity iff pairs of images are also surrounded by highly similar images that should also recursively share the same context (see Sect. 2.2; Figs. 1, 2). The regularization term is quadratic, it controls the smoothness of the learned kernel and it allows us to obtain explicit kernel maps (see Sect. 2.4). Again, our proposed method goes beyond the use of usual low level features and usual context free kernels (established as the standard baseline in image annotation) in order to design a family of kernels applicable to annotation and suitable to integrate the “contextual” information taken from tagged links in interconnected datasets. In the proposed context-aware kernel, two images (even with different visual content and even sharing different tags) will be declared as similar if they share the same visual context (see also Fig. 1). This is usually useful as tags in interconnected data may be noisy and misspelled. Furthermore, the intrinsic visual content of images might not always be relevant especially for concepts exhibiting large variation of their visual aspects.

Following the previous discussion and targeted goals, the main contributions of this work include:
An update of our objective function in [65] using a new definition of context. This function is also based on quadratic regularization and it combines content and context via a single parameter. The novelty resides in the new definition of context which is now relational (i.e., it makes it possible to diffuse kernel values through the topology of the graph enclosing the interconnected images), while context in [65], is geometric (i.e., it diffuses kernel values through the geometric structure of interest points inside images taken individually) and no “image-to-image” diffusion is achieved in [65] in contrast to the current contribution (see again Sect. 2.2; Figs. 1, 2).
With this new definition of context, we show that the theoretical properties of our kernel solution are still valid but with different interpretations and new extensions; mainly
(i)
the upper-bound (about the weight of context, that guarantees convergence of the learned kernel to a fixed-point), even though sketched in a similar way, has a different interpretation compared to the one in [65]; indeed, it depends now on row-stochastic adjacency matrices of relational contexts which are sparser (compared to geometric contexts) and this leads to loose bounds and easy to obtain convergence and also fast computation (see also late Sects. 2.4, 3.4; Table 3).
(ii)
the positive definiteness shows that the obtained recursive kernel solution can be written as a dot product, involving “explicit” kernel maps; provided that “explicit” kernel maps are also used for initialization. As a novel extension, we show how explicit kernel maps can be obtained for the popular and the powerful histogram intersection kernel (in contrast to [65] where KPCA is used to generate explicit maps for these kernel initializations). With this extension, and in spite of the non-linearity of our kernels, their maps are explicit, so one may use extremely fast primal-SVM solvers in order to handle large scale datasets
Such as stochastic gradient descent [10]. When the kernel map is explicit, the complexity of this method is linear in the size of the training data instead of quadratic (as in [67, 68]). and without the overhead of pre-computing gram matrices and solving quadratic programming (QP) problems (see also Sect. 3.4; Table 3).
In this paper, the definition of kernel between images is taken directly from the fixed-point solution of our objective function, while in [65], an extra step of “pooling” is achieved by plugging the fixed-point into the convolution kernel (see more details in [65]).
Finally, our participation to the challenging ImageCLEF 2013 photo annotation benchmark is discussed in details. Note that this benchmark is more recent, challenging and suitable compared to the one used in [65], as it has more concepts and different sources of context. This official participation (scored by the organizers) shows the first rank of our method among 58 participants’ runs belonging to 13 international labs.
The remainder of this paper is organized as follows: Section 2 describes our kernel map design procedure and some theoretical properties of the designed kernels, mainly their convergence and their explicit positive definiteness. Section 3 shows the application of the method to image annotation using the ImageCLEF 2013 benchmark and discusses different issues of the proposed method, mainly its complexity. Finally, we conclude the paper while providing possible extensions for a future work.

We plugged the learned kernel maps (10) into support vector classifiers in order to evaluate their performance. The targeted task is image annotation also known as “concept detection”; given a picture, the goal is to predict which concepts (classes) are present into that picture. For this purpose, we trained “one-versus-all” SVM classifiers for each concept to detect concepts in dev and test images. We run these experiments on the challenging ImageCLEF 2013 Photo Annotation database

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: We introduced in this paper a novel context-aware kernel map learning algorithm for interconnected image annotation. The purpose of this contribution and its main take home message is how to upgrade existing usual kernels, with context, in order to enhance their performances when plugged into SVMs.

Our designed kernel is able to recursively diffuse the similarity from/to larger and more influencing contexts; see Fig. (2) (i.e., two images are considered similar if their neighbors are similar and if the neighbors of their neighbors are similar too, etc.) so resulting into a recursive definition and propagation/diffusion of similarity through the structure of the adjacency graph of images. Indeed, the context-aware kernel exploits pairwise (local) as well as higher order interactions (resulting from recursion) in order to enhance similarity. Our comparison in Table 1 corroborates this statement as the learned context-aware kernel maps show consistent gain compared to the baselines.

Even though the method successfully tackles image annotation in the challenging ImageCLEF 2013 and obtained the first rank, it is generic and could easily be extended to classification tasks in other neighboring fields, including text comparison in document classification, translation or sequence comparison in bioinformatics. The main difference resides in the definition of context in these applications.
